summary: A letter from Senator Ben Sasse to Attorney General William Barr dated August 10, 2019, expressing outrage and demanding answers following the apparent suicide of Jeffrey Epstein while in federal custody. The letter criticizes the Department of Justice's failure to prevent Epstein's death, highlights the risk to justice for his victims and co-conspirators, and poses four urgent questions regarding the circumstances of his incarceration and death.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.role: United States Senator, Chairman of Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Oversight
persons.context: Author of the letter to Attorney General Barr, demanding investigations and accountability for the failure to prevent Jeffrey Epstein's suicide and to secure justice for his victims.

persons.name: William P. Barr
persons.role: Attorney General of the United States
persons.context: Recipient of the letter, held responsible for the Department of Justice's custody and prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein, and called upon to order investigations and secure evidence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Accused financier, indicted child sex trafficker
persons.context: The wealthy American financier indicted on charges of running an international child sex trafficking ring, who was found dead by apparent suicide in federal custody on the date of the letter.

connections.description: Senator Sasse is writing officially to Attorney General Barr to demand action and answers regarding the Epstein case, holding the DOJ accountable.
Senator Sasse, as a judiciary subcommittee chairman, is overseeing the case and expressing outrage at the failure to prevent Epstein's suicide and secure justice.
As Attorney General, Barr is responsible for the Department of Justice which had custody of and was prosecuting Epstein.

events.title: Epstein's arrest

events.title: Non-prosecution agreement
events.description: A 2008 non-prosecution agreement for Epstein that the Department of Justice had opened an investigation into for being mishandled.

events.title: Previous possible suicide attempt
events.description: Less than three weeks before his death, Epstein was found injured and semi-conscious in his cell from a possible suicide attempt.

locations: U.S. Department of Justice, Washington, DC
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead by apparent suicide in federal custody on August 10, 2019.
Epstein had a previous possible suicide attempt less than three weeks prior, after which he may have been placed on and then taken off suicide watch.
Senator Sasse demands investigations into the Bureau of Prisons' mismanagement and any possible criminal activity surrounding Epstein's death.
The letter emphasizes that Epstein's death deprives victims of confronting him and makes it harder to hold his co-conspirators and other powerful men accountable.
Sasse calls for the immediate securing of all evidence related to Epstein's co-conspirators to prevent further loss of testimony or evidence.
